qa_pairs.question: What are the key sectors in which Ekagrata Inc., the company led by Prashant Pathak, has diversified its assets, and what notable business ventures has he been involved in through his career?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Ekagrata Inc., led by Prashant Pathak, has diversified its assets into key sectors including food, agriculture, infrastructure, food-security, specialty manufacturing of hardware technologies, and digital commerce.<cite>[S2]</cite></statement> <statement>Pathak has been involved in notable business ventures such as his role at McKinsey & Company, where he led practices in telecom, financial services, and corporate finance.<cite>[S7]</cite></statement> <statement>He co-founded ReichmannHauer Capital Partners, an investment firm, and was part of the team that built the Olympia & York commercial real estate empire, developing landmarks like Toronto's First Canadian Place and London's Canary Wharf.<cite>[S8][S9][S10]</cite></statement> <statement>Pathak contributed to the creation and successful exit of Minacs, a business formed by combining Minacs, TransWorks, and Black Photo Corporation, which was later sold to Telus Corp.<cite>[S11]</cite></statement> <statement>He led the strategic process that resulted in the NYSE listing of PARTS iD Inc., following a business combination of Legacy Acquisition Corp. and Onyx Enterprise Int'l Corp.<cite>[S13]</cite></statement> <statement>Additionally, Pathak has been involved in the food and agricultural sector in China, as noted in his work with Canadian companies and international linkages.<cite>[S18]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] Prashant Pathak


# Prashant Pathak



**Prashant Shanker Pathak** (born 1972) is a Canadian investor and businessman who lives in Toronto. [S2] He is the CEO of Ekagrata Inc., a private investment and diversified holding company with assets in food, agriculture, infrastructure, food-security, specialty manufacturing of hardware technologies, and digital commerce. [S3] ## Education

Prashant Pathak studied at St. [S4] Francis' College, Lucknow before he completed a BTech degree in electrical engineering from The Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) and an MBA from INSEAD with distinction. [S5] He also completed a diploma in fuzzy logic from IIT Kanpur. [S6] ## Career

Pathak joined and was elected as a partner at McKinsey & Company, where he was leader of the North American Telecom Practice, the Financial Services Practices and also a leader of the Canadian Strategy & Corporate Finance Practice. [S7] After this he became the managing partner of ReichmannHauer Capital Partners, an investing and private equity firm based in Toronto focused on business building. [S8] He along with Philip Reichmann and Frank Hauer launched the business in 2006. [S9] His partners were part of the leadership that built the original Olympia & York commercial real estate empire, which developed landmark properties such as Toronto's First Canadian Place and London's Canary Wharf. [S10] He led the successful investments and exit in several businesses including Minacs, a business he helped create through the combination of Minacs with TransWorks an Indian BPO company and Black Photo Corporation that has over 116 premium stores across Canada, the company was purchased from Fujifilm in 2007 and sold to Telus corp. [S11] in 2010. [S12] He went on to lead the strategic process that led to the creation and listing on NYSE of PARTS iD Inc.(NYSE: ID), formed following the business combination of Legacy Acquisition Corp.(NYSE:LGC) and Onyx Enterprise Int'l Corp. [S13] ## Public causes and philanthropy

Pathak is engaged with several community and public causes. [S14] He helps run a social venture capital fund initiative, Project Beyshick, that nurtures prosperity and financial independence amongst First Nations communities and individuals by encouraging and mentoring entrepreneurial efforts. [S15] The project was co-founded by Toronto-based entrepreneur & philanthropist Aditya Jha, Ontario Regional Chief Stan Beardy, and his mentee Ashutosh Jha. [S16] In past, he was also involved with UNICEF Canada's $3-million HIV/AIDS program campaign. [S17] He is an active supporter in building export and international linkages of Canadian companies and has been involved in multiple delegations and efforts of the Canadian provincial and federal governments in building bridges with Asia, and in particular India, and, in China where he has recently been involved in the food and agricultural sector. [S18] He has commented on Canada's poor relations with India as a result of short term thinking by leadership in Canada. [S19] Pathak has been a mentor to the accelerator and incubation program at Singularity University Labs (SU Labs). [S20] In 2017 he joined the board of directors of the University of Guelph and retired from the board in June 2023. [S21] He has also served on the Board of MaRS Discovery District one of North America's largest urban innovation hubs and served on the board of the Fields Institute a leading international centre for research in mathematical sciences. [S22] ## Philosophy

At the PBD Canada 2011, Pathak was a speaker at the interactive panel discussion on engaging "Global Indians". [S23] He suggested that, to understand the global Indians, one should study (1.) monarch butterfly (multi-generation round trip between South and North America), (2.) blue wildebeest (survival of blue wildebeest over the black wildebeest that nearly were extinct), and the (3.) bees (how they are essential for existence of human life by being the pollination agent for plants). [S24] He described this approach as the "Three-B" approach to understanding how to engage the "Global Indians".

Passage 2:
[S25] ## Appointments and awards

Pathak has been an appointee of the Government of Canada to the BDC board and served for approximately a decade. [S26] BDC is
crown corporation financial institution wholly owned by the Government of Canada. [S27] He is an executive in residence with the Asia Pacific Foundation of Canada, created by an Act of Parliament in 1984, APFC is an independent, not-for-profit think-tank on Canada's relations with Asia. [S28] He was previously on the board of the North York General Hospital, a leading multi-site regional teaching hospital servicing people in north central Toronto and southern York Region. [S29] He was named as one of "Canada's Top 40 Under 40" in 2009 by Caldwell Partners. [S30] In 2009, Pathak was named to Rediff India Abroad's "Power List". [S31] He was honoured by the Indo Canada Chamber of Commerce in 2015 for his business achievements and strengthening bilateral ties between Canada and India.

qa_pairs.question: How did Prashant Pathak contribute to community and public causes, and what specific initiatives or organizations was he involved with in his philanthropic efforts?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Prashant Pathak contributed to community and public causes through various initiatives, including running a social venture capital fund called Project Beyshick, which supports First Nations communities by fostering entrepreneurship.<cite>[S15][S16]</cite></statement> <statement>He was involved with UNICEF Canada's $3-million HIV/AIDS program campaign, demonstrating his commitment to public health initiatives.<cite>[S17]</cite></statement> <statement>Pathak mentored participants in the accelerator and incubation program at Singularity University Labs, focusing on fostering innovation and entrepreneurial growth.<cite>[S20]</cite></statement> <statement>He served on the boards of organizations such as the University of Guelph, MaRS Discovery District, and the Fields Institute, contributing to education, innovation, and mathematical sciences research.<cite>[S21][S22]</cite></statement> <statement>Pathak actively supported building international linkages for Canadian companies, particularly in Asia and India, and advocated for stronger bilateral relations between Canada and India.<cite>[S18][S19]</cite></statement>

qa_pairs.question: What roles and appointments has Prashant Pathak held in public and academic institutions, and how do these reflect his broader influence beyond business ventures?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Prashant Pathak has held roles in public and academic institutions, including serving on the board of the University of Guelph from 2017 to 2023 and the MaRS Discovery District, a major innovation hub, as well as the Fields Institute for mathematical sciences research.<cite>[S21][S22]</cite></statement> <statement>He was appointed to the Business Development Bank of Canada (BDC) board, a government-owned financial institution, and served as an executive in residence with the Asia Pacific Foundation of Canada, a think-tank focused on Canada-Asia relations.<cite>[S25][S28]</cite></statement> <statement>Pathak also served on the board of North York General Hospital, a regional teaching hospital, and engaged in philanthropy through initiatives like Project Beyshick, which supports First Nations entrepreneurship, and mentorship at Singularity University Labs.<cite>[S29][S14][S20]</cite></statement> <statement>His involvement in public causes, such as UNICEF Canada's HIV/AIDS campaign and advocacy for stronger Canada-India relations, reflects his influence in shaping policy and international partnerships beyond business ventures.<cite>[S17][S19]</cite></statement> <statement>Additionally, his academic contributions include speaking engagements on global Indian diaspora strategies, such as his "Three-B" approach discussed at PBD Canada 2011, highlighting his thought leadership in cross-cultural and economic integration.<cite>[S23][S24]</cite></statement>

[S24] He described this approach as the "Three-B" approach to understanding how to engage the "Global Indians".

Passage 2:
[S25] ## Appointments and awards

Pathak has been an appointee of the Government of Canada to the BDC board and served for approximately a decade. [S26] BDC is
crown corporation financial institution wholly owned by the Government of Canada. [S27] He is an executive in residence with the Asia Pacific Foundation of Canada, created by an Act of Parliament in 1984, APFC is an independent, not-for-profit think-tank on Canada's relations with Asia. [S28] He was previously on the board of the North York General Hospital, a leading multi-site regional teaching hospital servicing people in north central Toronto and southern York Region. [S29] He was named as one of "Canada's Top 40 Under 40" in 2009 by Caldwell Partners. [S30] In 2009, Pathak was named to Rediff India Abroad's "Power List". [S31] He was honoured by the Indo Canada Chamber of Commerce in 2015 for his business achievements and strengthening bilateral ties between Canada and India.
chunk_list:
[S1] Prashant Pathak


# Prashant Pathak



**Prashant Shanker Pathak** (born 1972) is a Canadian investor and businessman who lives in Toronto. [S2] He is the CEO of Ekagrata Inc., a private investment and diversified holding company with assets in food, agriculture, infrastructure, food-security, specialty manufacturing of hardware technologies, and digital commerce. [S3] ## Education

Prashant Pathak studied at St. [S4] Francis' College, Lucknow before he completed a BTech degree in electrical engineering from The Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) and an MBA from INSEAD with distinction. [S5] He also completed a diploma in fuzzy logic from IIT Kanpur. [S6] ## Career

Pathak joined and was elected as a partner at McKinsey & Company, where he was leader of the North American Telecom Practice, the Financial Services Practices and also a leader of the Canadian Strategy & Corporate Finance Practice. [S7] After this he became the managing partner of ReichmannHauer Capital Partners, an investing and private equity firm based in Toronto focused on business building. [S8] He along with Philip Reichmann and Frank Hauer launched the business in 2006. [S9] His partners were part of the leadership that built the original Olympia & York commercial real estate empire, which developed landmark properties such as Toronto's First Canadian Place and London's Canary Wharf. [S10] He led the successful investments and exit in several businesses including Minacs, a business he helped create through the combination of Minacs with TransWorks an Indian BPO company and Black Photo Corporation that has over 116 premium stores across Canada, the company was purchased from Fujifilm in 2007 and sold to Telus corp. [S11] in 2010. [S12] He went on to lead the strategic process that led to the creation and listing on NYSE of PARTS iD Inc.(NYSE: ID), formed following the business combination of Legacy Acquisition Corp.(NYSE:LGC) and Onyx Enterprise Int'l Corp. [S13] ## Public causes and philanthropy

Pathak is engaged with several community and public causes. [S14] He helps run a social venture capital fund initiative, Project Beyshick, that nurtures prosperity and financial independence amongst First Nations communities and individuals by encouraging and mentoring entrepreneurial efforts. [S15] The project was co-founded by Toronto-based entrepreneur & philanthropist Aditya Jha, Ontario Regional Chief Stan Beardy, and his mentee Ashutosh Jha. [S16] In past, he was also involved with UNICEF Canada's $3-million HIV/AIDS program campaign. [S17] He is an active supporter in building export and international linkages of Canadian companies and has been involved in multiple delegations and efforts of the Canadian provincial and federal governments in building bridges with Asia, and in particular India, and, in China where he has recently been involved in the food and agricultural sector. [S18] He has commented on Canada's poor relations with India as a result of short term thinking by leadership in Canada. [S19] Pathak has been a mentor to the accelerator and incubation program at Singularity University Labs (SU Labs). [S20] In 2017 he joined the board of directors of the University of Guelph and retired from the board in June 2023. [S21] He has also served on the Board of MaRS Discovery District one of North America's largest urban innovation hubs and served on the board of the Fields Institute a leading international centre for research in mathematical sciences. [S22] ## Philosophy

At the PBD Canada 2011, Pathak was a speaker at the interactive panel discussion on engaging "Global Indians". [S23] He suggested that, to understand the global Indians, one should study (1.) monarch butterfly (multi-generation round trip between South and North America), (2.) blue wildebeest (survival of blue wildebeest over the black wildebeest that nearly were extinct), and the (3.) bees (how they are essential for existence of human life by being the pollination agent for plants). [S24] He described this approach as the "Three-B" approach to understanding how to engage the "Global Indians".

[S25] ## Appointments and awards

Pathak has been an appointee of the Government of Canada to the BDC board and served for approximately a decade. [S26] BDC is
crown corporation financial institution wholly owned by the Government of Canada. [S27] He is an executive in residence with the Asia Pacific Foundation of Canada, created by an Act of Parliament in 1984, APFC is an independent, not-for-profit think-tank on Canada's relations with Asia. [S28] He was previously on the board of the North York General Hospital, a leading multi-site regional teaching hospital servicing people in north central Toronto and southern York Region. [S29] He was named as one of "Canada's Top 40 Under 40" in 2009 by Caldwell Partners. [S30] In 2009, Pathak was named to Rediff India Abroad's "Power List". [S31] He was honoured by the Indo Canada Chamber of Commerce in 2015 for his business achievements and strengthening bilateral ties between Canada and India.

qa_pairs.question: What is the significance of Prashant Pathak's 'Three-B' approach to understanding 'Global Indians,' and which natural phenomena did he reference to illustrate this philosophy?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Prashant Pathak's 'Three-B' approach to understanding 'Global Indians' emphasizes using natural phenomena as metaphors to analyze their transnational connections and resilience. This framework highlights how global Indians, like these natural entities, exhibit adaptability and interconnectedness across regions.<cite>[S23][S24]</cite></statement><statement>Pathak referenced the monarch butterfly (multi-generation round trip between South and North America), the blue wildebeest (survival over the black wildebeest), and bees (essential for pollination and human life) to illustrate the 'Three-B' philosophy.<cite>[S24]</cite></statement>
